messages: b8ac460f16efd92d9e259415a4930199 (20:16): anyone remember when mktemp was added to solaris?
b8ac460f16efd92d9e259415a4930199 (20:17): ( the tool to make random file names )
778d97eab00032b3f494f2988d83c295 (20:17): man mktemp might know
b8ac460f16efd92d9e259415a4930199 (20:19): it just says the interface is evolving, at least the one i found in sun's web page

8055e871523d029ea1618a39edaf008f (20:31): anyone tried solaris on the via epia platform?
73659c75836322dfd0df5f56972b2c27 (20:32): prolly invalid operands
8055e871523d029ea1618a39edaf008f (20:32): but it's listed in the HCL o_O
73659c75836322dfd0df5f56972b2c27 (20:33): I have a quite old one
d29f7858616789349f2e17f17eaa3395 (20:33): elflord: I used it for a lot of time
8055e871523d029ea1618a39edaf008f (20:33): i have a via epia 5000 here, 533 mhz processor
d29f7858616789349f2e17f17eaa3395 (20:33): elflord: on 2 epia pd6000 fanless
8055e871523d029ea1618a39edaf008f (20:33): gives me kernel panics at random stages
d29f7858616789349f2e17f17eaa3395 (20:34): I used it in production on an 1U 2boards rack from travla.com :P
73659c75836322dfd0df5f56972b2c27 (20:34): I have a Nehemiah chip
73659c75836322dfd0df5f56972b2c27 (20:34): no boot.. nothing
d29f7858616789349f2e17f17eaa3395 (20:34): I setup 2 mysql istances replicating, no problems
8055e871523d029ea1618a39edaf008f (20:34): okay, it's no nehemiah here
8055e871523d029ea1618a39edaf008f (20:35): so i assume the ram has a defect
73659c75836322dfd0df5f56972b2c27 (20:35): random stages is mostprobably RAM
8055e871523d029ea1618a39edaf008f (20:35): since i already tried the second board...
30304b9bc0a292e1440982ddf6a0c186 (20:35): some issues with oldboot, and you need some external drivers, and don't expect usb2.0 to work, apart from that, it works fine
73659c75836322dfd0df5f56972b2c27 (20:36): board get seldomly random... memory does mostly
d29f7858616789349f2e17f17eaa3395 (20:37): well, sorry, I had the M 6000 with solaris, I used the pd6000 only with openbsd as of now...
73659c75836322dfd0df5f56972b2c27 (20:38): anyone an idea 'bout the ZFS port of FreeBSD *
73659c75836322dfd0df5f56972b2c27 (20:38): workable already ?
8055e871523d029ea1618a39edaf008f (20:39): dunno, but there's a lively discussion of the matter on the freebsd-current mailing list
8055e871523d029ea1618a39edaf008f (20:39): maybe you want to check out the archives
8055e871523d029ea1618a39edaf008f (20:40): but if i recall it right, there's already something working ^^
73659c75836322dfd0df5f56972b2c27 (20:40): long time ago... but BSD *with* zfs might be worth looking @ again
8055e871523d029ea1618a39edaf008f (20:40): in fact i like freebsd very much and used it for several years as primary system ^^
73659c75836322dfd0df5f56972b2c27 (20:44): I did too, until Linux overwhelmed *BSD by features
73659c75836322dfd0df5f56972b2c27 (20:45): and certainly in drivers
495dc924195a6e2676bb11153b05b166 (20:45): and political bullshit as well
8055e871523d029ea1618a39edaf008f (20:45): yeah, thats right :/
73659c75836322dfd0df5f56972b2c27 (20:46): 's like the debian hassle
8055e871523d029ea1618a39edaf008f (20:46): i started disliking linux when they forced this webcam guy into the stop of development of his driver because of some binary-only components :/
73659c75836322dfd0df5f56972b2c27 (20:46): some politics don't get understood
73659c75836322dfd0df5f56972b2c27 (20:46): and than become rules
a4a16fa360254e973a304a48ebe8fecd (20:47): forcing someone to do something is different than telling them that they don't want your binary only crap...

8055e871523d029ea1618a39edaf008f (20:47): i think when you put much efforts into developing drivers etc. and then somebody shows up telling you that you can't continue because of (self-made!!!) political issues... i'd hate him ^^
73659c75836322dfd0df5f56972b2c27 (20:48): I would sadly live to far away to stick the code on a CDROm up into where his back changes name
d29f7858616789349f2e17f17eaa3395 (20:48): hey, just a little advice, is there something better of ntop in your opinion? :)
a4a16fa360254e973a304a48ebe8fecd (20:49): sickness: for what?
d29f7858616789349f2e17f17eaa3395 (20:49): Justin: for lan analysis
a4a16fa360254e973a304a48ebe8fecd (20:49): what kind of analysis? :)
73659c75836322dfd0df5f56972b2c27 (20:50): ethereal is ported, IIRC
d29f7858616789349f2e17f17eaa3395 (20:50): traffic/protocols/congestion
d29f7858616789349f2e17f17eaa3395 (20:50): ethereal is not like ntop...
73659c75836322dfd0df5f56972b2c27 (20:50): no, not for congestion, no :-)
d29f7858616789349f2e17f17eaa3395 (20:50): well, it's a better program, but it does different things...
a4a16fa360254e973a304a48ebe8fecd (20:50): what kind of link are you looking to analyze?
a4a16fa360254e973a304a48ebe8fecd (20:51): netflow tools are good
d29f7858616789349f2e17f17eaa3395 (20:51): tnx, I'll try to try netflow :)
a4a16fa360254e973a304a48ebe8fecd (20:51): you can use netflow with ntop, but I've had probles getting ntop to scale
a4a16fa360254e973a304a48ebe8fecd (20:52): for netflow, nfsen is nice
d29f7858616789349f2e17f17eaa3395 (20:52): uh oh, but netflow is only for cisco gear!
a4a16fa360254e973a304a48ebe8fecd (20:52): no, you can run the collector on a unix box:
a4a16fa360254e973a304a48ebe8fecd (20:52): fprobe-ng - export captured traffic to remote NetFlow Collector
8055e871523d029ea1618a39edaf008f (20:54): thanks for your help, i'll be back within the hour reporting if it worked ^^
